login.explaination: The tool dedicated to the application of the Bilan Carbone® method, developed by the Association for the Low Carbon Transition (ABC), and accessible to all of our members: Consulting and Research, Business, Association and Public Sector
login.question: A question? Read the <link>FAQ</link> or <support>contact us</support>!

glossary.title: Glossary
glossary.exports: Take into account emissions that have not been validated
glossary.exportsDescription: Within a Bilan Carbone®, you can choose to display all the emissions you have entered, or only those that have been validated by a validator.
glossary.caUnitsDescription: Specify the unit you wish to use for turnover figures.

study.firstStudyMessage: It's time to get started! We invite you to create your first bilan.
study.validatedOnlyDescription: For each Bilan Carbone®, one or more validators can be defined. These validators are responsible for validating the sources of emissions once they have been entered by the study's contributors and editors. By default, only validated emissions appear in your results, but you can change this behaviour via the "Settings" menu.
study.withDependencies: The new Bilan Carbone® method introduces the concept of responsibility and dependency. It is strongly recommended that the results of the Bilan Carbone® are presented with and without the "Use in dependence" sub-post, as the organisation is generally not in a position to act easily on this sub-post. On the other hand, this sub-component remains crucial for understanding the risks to which the organisation is exposed, particularly if it is dependent on high-carbon sectors or activities. The final result should include dependency. For more information on these new concepts, please consult <link>this page</link>.
study.selectSite: Before filling in the details, choose a site

glossary.title: Glossaire
glossary.validatorEmailDescription: For each Bilan Carbone®, one or more validators can be defined. These validators are responsible for validating the sources of emissions once they have been entered by the study's contributors and editors. By default, only validated emissions appear in your results, but you can change this behaviour via the "Parameters" menu.
glossary.typeDescription: The new version of the Bilan Carbone® method introduces three levels of maturity for organisations' Bilan Carbone®. For more details, please consult <link>this page</link>.
glossary.visibilityDescription: Choose whether your study should be public, i.e. accessible to all your colleagues entered on the My organisation > my team page (link to the page), or private, i.e. only accessible to the people you add on the study framework page. Your organisation's admins have access to all studies, whether public or private.
glossary.exportsDescription: By default, the results are returned in Bilan Carbone® format, but it is possible to obtain the results in the formats required by several other carbon accounting methods, such as the Bilan GES règlementaire, which is the French regulatory method.
glossary.controlDescription: The control mode is a data item required by certain carbon accounting methods, such as the regulatory GHG Balance or the GHG Protocol. In order to obtain the results in the formats requested by these methods, you will need to characterise the different sources of emissions when you enter them, which will determine into which of the existing categories within these methods (the equivalent of the posts and sub-posts within the Bilan Carbone® method) the emissions will be broken down. Depending on the control mode selected, the characterisations available for the different sources of emissions vary. For more details on the control modes, please consult the methodological guides for the methods in question. We strongly recommend that you use the "Operational Control" control mode, which is by far the most common.

role.introduction: From this page, you can manage the members of your team involved in the Bilan Carbone®. In all cases, the administrators of your organisation have access to all your studies as validators. If your study is public, members of your organisation (employees, managers) automatically have read access to it. You can also add people from outside your organisation via this menu.
role.Validator_description: Has full rights over the study and can validate the emission sources entered by validators, editors and contributors.
role.Editor_description: Has all rights to the study except for validation of emission sources.
role.Reader_description: Can only read the study and export its information.
role.Not authorized: You are not allowed to do this action

For more information on the contributor interface, please see our <link>FAQ</link>.

post.EmissionsLieesAuChangementDAffectationDe: Emissions related to land use change (LUC)
post.BiensEtMatieresEnApprocheMonetaire: Goods and materials in monetary approach
post.DeplacementsProfessionnels: Employee travel in the context of work
post.ConsommationDEnergieEnFinDeVie: Energy consumption at end of life
post.TraitementDesDechetsEnFinDeVie: Waste treatment at end of life
post.TraitementDesEmballagesEnFinDeVie: Packaging treatment at end of life

glossaryDescription.DechetsDirects: This post covers all emissions linked to the management of waste produced (collection and treatment) within the organisation. It is divided into different sub-posts, each covering a different category of waste.
glossaryDescription.IntrantsBiensEtMatieres: This post covers emissions linked to the various flows of goods and materials entering the organisation. It is divided into different sub-posts, each covering a different category of material.
glossaryDescription.Immobilisations: All emissions linked to the purchase or long-term rental of durable goods (subject to accounting depreciation by the organisation).
glossaryDescription.FinDeVie: This post covers all emissions related to the future end-of-life of products sold within the timeframe.
glossaryDescription.DeplacementsDomicileTravail: Commuting to and from work for employees working within the organisation, including temporary staff, subcontractors and contractors.
glossaryDescription.DeplacementsProfessionnels: Business travel by employees in the course of their professional activity, whether or not the organisation owns the means of transport, and whether or not the travel takes place during working hours.
glossaryDescription.CombustiblesFossiles: For heating, industrial processes, electricity or steam production.
glossaryDescription.CombustiblesOrganiques: For heating, industrial processes, electricity or steam production.
glossaryDescription.Electricite: For heating, routine use, industrial processes and own electricity production.
glossaryDescription.Agriculture: Enteric fermentation of ruminants, livestock waste, use of nitrogen fertilisers, etc.
glossaryDescription.EmissionsLieesAuxProcedesIndustriels: Cement production, process emissions in the semiconductor industry, etc.
glossaryDescription.FretInterne: If the departure and arrival points are part of the organisational perimeter.
glossaryDescription.ServicesEnApprocheMonetaire: Various services received, accounted for via emission factors in monetary ratios.
glossaryDescription.MatiereDestineeAuxEmballages: In order to be able to focus the transition plan's actions on packaging, a sub-post dedicated to the material used in this packaging is available.
glossaryDescription.BiensEtMatieresEnApprocheMonetaire: A sub-section is also dedicated to materials for which emission factors in monetary ratios are used.
glossaryDescription.UtilisationEnResponsabilite: Products sold by the organisation within the timeframe under consideration over their entire lifespan, for which the organisation is directly responsible ([in italisque] for a manufacturer of meal trays served on aircraft, the responsible use corresponds to the energy used to cool and heat the meal tray).
glossaryDescription.UtilisationEnDependance: Products sold by the organisation within the timeframe under consideration over their entire lifespan, for which the organisation is not directly responsible but which its activity contributes to emitting ([in italics] For a manufacturer of meal trays served in an aircraft, the dependent use corresponds to the emissions for the entire flight).

create.title: Add an emission factor
create.name: Name
create.namePlaceholder: Give a name to your emission Factor

glossary.title: Glossary
glossary.detailedGESDescription: If you know the proportion of emissions due to the different GHGs for your emission factor, you can enter it using this function. The Bilan Carbone® method does not use this breakdown, as knowing the distribution of emissions across the different GHGs complicates the results without providing any useful information for building the transition plan. However, this breakdown of emissions by GHG is useful if you wish to obtain the various exports offered by BC+.

multipleDescription.introduction: Some emission factors have components, i.e. they are made up of different emissions from different activities. For example, emission factors for electricity in France are classically broken down into three components:
multipleDescription.upstream: Upstream, which takes into account emissions linked to the construction of electricity generation infrastructure and its transmission to the grid.
multipleDescription.combustion: , which takes into account emissions linked to the production of electricity itself (coal combustion, etc.).
multipleDescription.loss: Losses, which take account of losses in the form of heat during the transmission of electricity on the network.
multipleDescription.conclusion: This disaggregation is not used in the Bilan Carbone® method, but is used to break down the emissions of the various components within the categories for exports (for the regulatory GHG balance, using the same example, and if the source of emissions is "Operated", "upstream" emissions, "combustion at the power plant" and "losses" are broken down within categories 4.1, 1.2 and 4.1 respectively).. We strongly recommend that you do not use this function if you are not familiar with the allocations within the regulatory GHG balance.

glossary.postDescription: You must choose the item(s) and sub-item(s) within which your emission factor will be selectable.

modal.confirm-edition: Are you sure you want to edit this emission factor
modal.confirm-deletion: Are you sure you want to delete this emission factor
modal.title: Edit the emission factor
modal.description: <warning>If you've used this emission factor in a study, the changes will be applied to all the emission sources that use it.</warning> If you want to create a new version, create a new one.

role.ADMIN_description: An administrator has full rights to the organisation's account and to all studies for his organization (whether public or private). It is impossible to change an administrator role on a study of his organization.
role.ADMIN_description_CR: An administrator has full rights to the organisation's and the organization clients' account and studies (whether public or private). It is impossible to change an administrator role on a study of his organization or one of its clients.
role.GESTIONNAIRE_description: A manager has full rights over the organisation's account, but no rights over studies. He is by default reader on public studies of his organization.
role.GESTIONNAIRE_description_CR: A manager has full rights over the organisation's account, but no rights over customers or studies. He is by default reader on its organization's or its clients public studies.
role.COLLABORATOR_description: A collaborator is a person trained in the Bilan Carbone® method. They have no rights to the organisation's account but can create studies. They have access to their organization's public studies with the role editor by default.
role.COLLABORATOR_description_CR: A collaborator is a person trained in the Bilan Carbone® method. They have no rights to the organisation's account but can create clients and studies. They only have access to their organization's or their organization clients public studies with the role editor by default.
role.DEFAULT_description: A member of the organisation has no specific rights over the organisation, the team or studies. By default, they are readers of all their organisation's public Bilans Carbone®.
role.DEFAULT_description_CR: A member of the organisation has no specific rights over the organisation, the team, their clients or studies. By default, they are readers of all their organisation's or their organization's clients public Bilans Carbone®.
role.Not authorized: You are not allowed to do this action
role.More than one: There must be at least one admin or manager in the organization

glossary.title: Glossary
glossary.typeDescription: The type of data is a denomination introduced by the new Bilan Carbone® method, which complements the calculation of uncertainties. For more information on the different types of data, please consult <link>this page</link>.
glossary.qualityDescription: Uncertainties are now calculated using qualitative notes on the quality of the emission factor and the quality of the activity data. The scores for the emission factor are taken directly from the databases, but those for the activity data must be entered. For more information on how scores are awarded, please consult <link>this page</link>.

deleteDialog.title: Are you sur you want to delete this emission source?
deleteDialog.description: <warning>All data entered will be permanently lost,</warning> and any contributors will no longer have access to this emission source.

A problem has occurred. Try returning to the home page.

If this does not work, contact our support at or try to reconnect.

onboarding.title-1: Welcome to BC+! Before you start, please set up your organization
onboarding.titleDescription-1: We’ve pre-filled some information about your organization (association, company, ...) based on your membership with ABC. You can update your organization’s name now, or at any time in BC+ via the "Organization" section.
onboarding.titleDescription-2: You can already add your team members! You’ll still be able to add new people later via the "Team" section within the "Organization" menu.

step1.name: Name of my organization
step1.adminDescription: You have been trained to the Bilan Carbone® method : Thus, your have been attribued to the Admin role
step1.gestionnaireDescription: You have not been trained to the Bilan Carbone® method : Thus, your have been attribued to the Gestionnaire role

step2.crCollaboratorDescription: Create clients and realize their Bilan Carbone®
step2.gestionnaireDescription: Manages the organisation's account but does not have access to studies
step2.memberDescription: Has no rights over the organisation and is not necessarily trained to the Bilan Carbone® method.

checklist.title: Getting started on BC+
checklist.AddCollaboratorDetails: Add your colleagues so that they can help you draw up your organization's Bilan Carbone®.
checklist.AddClientDetails: Add your first client to start your Bilans Carbone®.
checklist.AddSiteCRDetails: Add sites to your <orga>organisation</orga> or to <client>one of your clients</client> so that you can set up emissions for each site. If your organisation or customer has only one site, create an 'All sites' site.
checklist.AddSiteOrgaDetails: Add sites to your <orga>organisation</orga> so that you can set up emissions for each site. If your organisation has only one site, create an 'All sites' site.
checklist.CreateFirstStudyDetails: Let's get started with your first Bilan Carbone®! Fill in the initial details, such as the date, name...
checklist.CreateFirstEmissionSourceDetails: Go to the first item/sub-item you wish to enter! Choose your emission factor, enter your activity data and make your first calculations.
checklist.ConsultResultsDetails: Now go to the "Results" page to view and export your emissions...
checklist.finished: You're ready to start using BC+! Feel free to consult the <faq>FAQ</faq> or contact us if you need anything.
